Package common

Class Path

  • java.lang.Object
    • common.Path
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Path>, Iterable<String>
    public class Path
extends Object
implements Iterable<String>, Comparable<Path>, Serializable
    Distributed filesystem paths.

    Objects of type Path are used by all filesystem interfaces. Path objects are immutable.

    The string representation of paths is a forward-slash-delimited sequence of path components (e.g., "/dir/file"). The root directory is represented as a single forward slash.

    The colon (':'), semicolon (';'), forward slash ('/'), and space (' ') characters are not permitted within path components. The forward slash is the delimiter between path components, colon and semicolon are avoided for OS reasons, and space is avoided to allow string parsing using space-delimiters.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • iterator

        public Iterator<String> iterator()
        Returns an iterator over the components of the path.

        The iterator cannot be used to modify the path object - the remove method is not supported.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<String>
        Returns:
        The iterator.

      • list

        public static Path[] list​(File directory)
                   throws FileNotFoundException
        Lists the paths of all files in a directory tree on the local filesystem.
        Parameters:
        directory - The root directory of the directory tree.
        Returns:
        An array of relative paths, one for each file in the directory tree.
        Throws:
        FileNotFoundException - If the root directory does not exist.
        IllegalArgumentException - If directory exists but does not refer to a directory.

      • isRoot

        public boolean isRoot()
        Determines whether the path represents the root directory.
        Returns:
        true if the path does represent the root directory, and false if it does not.

      • parent

        public Path parent()
        Returns the path to the parent of this path.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the path represents the root directory, and therefore has no parent.

      • last

        public String last()
        Returns the last component in the path.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the path represents the root directory, and therefore has no last component.

      • isSubpath

        public boolean isSubpath​(Path other)
        Determines if the given path is a subpath of this path.

        The other path is a subpath of this path if it is a prefix of this path. Note that by this definition, each path is a subpath of itself.

        Parameters:
        other - The path to be tested.
        Returns:
        true If and only if the other path is a subpath of this path.

        Parameters:
        root - The resulting File object is created relative to this directory.
        Returns:
        The File object.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo​(Path other)
        Compares this path to another.

        An ordering upon Path objects is provided to prevent deadlocks between applications that need to lock multiple filesystem objects simultaneously. By convention, paths that need to be locked simultaneously are locked in increasing order.

        Because locking a path requires locking every component along the path, the order is not arbitrary. For example, suppose the paths were ordered first by length, so that /etc precedes /bin/cat, which precedes /etc/dfs/conf.txt.

        Now, suppose two users are running two applications, such as two instances of cp. One needs to work with /etc and /bin/cat, and the other with /bin/cat and /etc/dfs/conf.txt.

        Then, if both applications follow the convention and lock paths in increasing order, the following situation can occur: the first application locks /etc. The second application locks /bin/cat. The first application tries to lock /bin/cat also, but gets blocked because the second application holds the lock. Now, the second application tries to lock /etc/dfs/conf.txt, and also gets blocked, because it would need to acquire the lock for /etc to do so. The two applications are now deadlocked.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<Path>
        Parameters:
        other - The other path.
        Returns:
        Zero if the two paths are equal, a negative number if this path precedes the other path, or a positive number if this path follows the other path.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(Object other)
        Compares two paths for equality.

        Two paths are equal if they share all the same components.

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        other - The other path.
        Returns:
        true if and only if the two paths are equal.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Converts the path to a string.

        The string may later be used as an argument to the Path(String) constructor.

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
